p: Lastly, socioeconomic inequalities in health are usually more marked in urban areas [25]. Climate change may act as an amplifier of these inequalities, as its impacts will put additional pressure on the vulnerable economies and societies that characterise many cities with Mediterranean climates [18]. Therefore, an approach is needed that not only identifies which populations are most vulnerable to the health effects of climate change, but also facilitates an evaluation of where injustices emerge, which affected groups in society are ignored and what processes exist to rectify these injustices.
